A.H. Redden Born Sept. 1875.

4 miles west of Town situated in county Kans.

One of eight children. Family came to Kansas in 1877.

Two years old. Plowed Red river in boat to Wyo.

Then to Homestead by oxcart 31 miles near water.

The town of Baldwin, Kansas.

Plenty schooling around 2½ or 3½ an elementary also. Due on house

remembered fields working out the door on due a month

holding his head on shoulder first at corner of the house.

received schooling in old log school at Baldwin

William 13 or 14 had to stay home and work for Dad on

farm milk cows. Drive them hauling hay on wood

in winter went about in horse pull in summer on

own increasing in similar terms of Shum was Nebraska

owned land a house on side farm until 1890 when 20 yrs

owned but a few years for farming around Baldwin. Hand

worked 97 in woods to help Wyo. 1898 at time to farm

with Uncle Monroe on

Homestead purchased 1900 to homestead

Reading into Kansas moved to 1901-1902 under government

summer near Joliet, Illinois

To winter under canvass

Then to South Dakota spring 1903 on Homestead Bridge pony

on buying stock West Yorkshire. 1904 to Jackson and

Homestead. Must say I will chew for that no lie

The life enjoyed every day

will send back of family on myself own terms
J.H. Reden Born Sept 7 1875.

4 miles west of Town Listowel in county Perth
Cent. of Irish settlement came to Manitoba in 1877
two years old. down Red river in boat to Wpg.
then to homestead by oxcart 31 miles near where
the town of Balmore stands.

Plenty Indians around Wpg an itinerant also. Deer on house
remember us kids looking out. The deer can see a moose
riding his head on shoreline post at corner of the house.
received schooling in old log school at Balmore.
When 13 or 14 had to stay home and work for Dad on
farm with cows. drive team hauling hay an wood
in winter went school in bare feet in summer on
snow crossings in winter some of them were meanwhile
never had a horse on the farm until 1890 when 20 yrs
worked out a few yrs for farmers around Balmore. spent
winter 97 in woods on lake Wpg. 98-99 at home on farm
1897 with store owner at Holland Manitoba. 1900 to Canada

Riding into Saskatchewan 1901-1902 with government
survey near Lake Manitoba to winter under canvas.

Then to Saskatoon spring 1903 on Railroad Bridge gang
on laying steel West Yorkton. 1904 to Saskatoon an
homestead. Great boy I will cheer for Sask. I like
the life enjoyed every day.

will send snap of family on myself an wife
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces in the sheets of paper. If there is not sufficient space to answer all the questions, the answers should be written on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1924, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer schooling life
- Pioneer housing and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., Canada. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask., Canada.

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to you; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. It is best to answer the questions to the best of your knowledge.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this Province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer File: What Did Western Canadian Farmers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered the questionnaire, please put a check mark here ( ).

Western Canadian Archives Questionnaire No. 2, entitled "Pioneer Education and Occupation Experience" is also available. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

Through Pioneer Experiences in Manitoba reading my book, I thought it would be a good idea to tell others about my experiences. I am now retired and have time to write about my life. I hope this will help others who are interested in pioneer experiences.
